learning_outcomes.description: Employ interaction design methods to inform the development of interactive technologies
Develop solutions to design problems through the creative application of interaction design methods and processes.
Create designs in the context of a large open-ended project, taking into account other, potentially conflicting, features.
Analyse complex problems and apply design patterns to design contextually appropriate solutions.
Demonstrate an ability to work collaboratively and effectively with others in a team towards shared project goals, while managing individual work

assessments.task_description:
Students forming teams and working on their projects is at the core of Studio-2 Interaction Design. As a part of this assessment, student teams will identify a problem space and develop a prototype solution, using various Interaction Design methods and techniques. Teams will follow a complete design cycle of exploring and understanding a problem, eliciting user requirements, creating engaging interaction designs, developing prototypes and testing/evaluating them in real-world situations. 

Teams will conduct two iterations of their prototypes and showcase their design prototypes and processes in week 8 (first iteration) and in week 13 (second iteration). Teams will submit a detailed project report representing their design and development processes.

This team-based assessment will be divided into three smaller-assessment milestones:

  1. Design Exhibit/Presentation of Iteration 1 (week 8): 10%
  2. Design Exhibit of Iteration 2 (week 13): 25%
  3. Project Report (14 Nov 2024): 15%


Milestone 1 is expected to be a work-in-progress activity, where a prototype will be exhibited during a regular studio session. It is expected that prototypes developed in this milestone are interactive and present the project ideas clearly. Prototypes may not be fully developed at this stage and there is no expectation of any user evaluations/testing in this milestone.

Milestone 2 is expected to show a final prototype, where the aesthetics and look-and-feel of prototypes is high-resolution. It is expected that findings from an adequate level of user engagement, testing or evaluation is incorporated in the prototype. 

Milestone 3 is expected to be a ~3000-word project report that should capture all aspects of the project.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
As a part of this assessment, students are asked to maintain a design journal throughout this studio course. The activities reported in students' design journal entries will also be discussed in the last assessment item: the in-person interview. Students should report their weekly project and design activities in their journals and provide evidence. A minimum of 9 journal entries are required, where students need to provide the following content on each journal entry: 1) a description of the design activity, 2) visual evidence of the activity through images, and 3) a statement on learning from the design activity. There will be a check-point in this assessment in week 8 studio, where at least 5 design journal entries are required to be completed by week 8. Failure to do so will lead to marks for this assessment capped at 4.

The interviews will be based on activities reported in students' design journal entries and their overall contributions to the team project. As this is a hurdle assessment, if a student receives a grade of 3 in this assessment, they will FAIL this course.
